body: We could resolve this with PSMore #7857

RE `TimeSpan`, PS 7 really, really needs a better default format for this this type because this is a bit of a spew:
```
05-05 11:27:19 1> Measure-Command { 6 * 7 }

Days              : 0
Hours             : 0
Minutes           : 0
Seconds           : 0
Milliseconds      : 6
Ticks             : 64564
TotalDays         : 7.47268518518518E-08
TotalHours        : 1.79344444444444E-06
TotalMinutes      : 0.000107606666666667
TotalSeconds      : 0.0064564
TotalMilliseconds : 6.4564
```
I would prefer to see this:
```
05-05 11:38:01 26> [TimeSpan]"1.15:22:15.003",[TimeSpan]"0.0:0:0.015" | % { $_.ToString("G"); }

1:15:22:15.0030000
0:00:00:00.0150000
```
Or maybe the humanized version:
```
05-05 11:42:25 36> [TimeSpan]"1.15:22:15.003",[TimeSpan]"0.0:0:0.015" | % {[Humanizer.TimeSpanHumanizeExtensions]::Humanize($_,5)}

1 day, 15 hours, 22 minutes, 15 seconds, 3 milliseconds
15 milliseconds
```
Although by default I think it should be the previous (more regular) version.  If you want the humanized version, maybe there should be a `Format-Humanized` command? 

This is related to #9518 but more general.

1 googolplex of YESes.

While my following example only works on PowerShell 5, I frequently want to use `Format-Custom` to view complex objects in reasonable ways.  For example:

```powershell
get-eventlog -LogName system -source "Service Control Manager"  | where eventid -cin  @(7000, 7038)  | select eventid,message,timewritten -Last 2 | format-custom
```

The problem here is that the default serialization of DateTime in PowerShell is ridiculous.  I end up with 142 useless lines of text. Compare the following brief log message to the one `Format-Custom` produces:

### Ideal
```
class EventLogEntry
{
  EventID = 7000
  Message = The SSISScaleOutWorker140 service failed to start due to the following error:
  %%1053
  TimeWritten = Monday, July 8, 2019 12:08:46 PM
}
```

### Actual
```
class EventLogEntry
{
  EventID = 7000
  Message = The SSISScaleOutWorker140 service failed to start due to the following error:
  %%1053
  TimeWritten =
    class DateTime
    {
      Date =
        class DateTime
        {
          Date =
            class DateTime
            {
              Date =
                class DateTime
                {
                  Date =
                    class DateTime
                    {
                      Date = 7/8/2019 12:00:00 AM
                      Day = 8
                      DayOfWeek = Monday
                      DayOfYear = 189
                      Hour = 0
                      Kind = Local
                      Millisecond = 0
                      Minute = 0
                      Month = 7
                      Second = 0
                      Ticks = 636981408000000000
                      TimeOfDay = 00:00:00
                      Year = 2019
                      DateTime = Monday, July 8, 2019 12:00:00 AM
                    }
                  Day = 8
                  DayOfWeek = Monday
                  DayOfYear = 189
                  Hour = 0
                  Kind = Local
                  Millisecond = 0
                  Minute = 0
                  Month = 7
                  Second = 0
                  Ticks = 636981408000000000
                  TimeOfDay =
                    class TimeSpan
                    {
                      Ticks = 0
                      Days = 0
                      Hours = 0
                      Milliseconds = 0
                      Minutes = 0
                      Seconds = 0
                      TotalDays = 0
                      TotalHours = 0
                      TotalMilliseconds = 0
                      TotalMinutes = 0
                      TotalSeconds = 0
                    }
                  Year = 2019
                  DateTime = Monday, July 8, 2019 12:00:00 AM
                }
              Day = 8
              DayOfWeek = Monday
              DayOfYear = 189
              Hour = 0
              Kind = Local
              Millisecond = 0
              Minute = 0
              Month = 7
              Second = 0
              Ticks = 636981408000000000
              TimeOfDay =
                class TimeSpan
                {
                  Ticks = 0
                  Days = 0
                  Hours = 0
                  Milliseconds = 0
                  Minutes = 0
                  Seconds = 0
                  TotalDays = 0
                  TotalHours = 0
                  TotalMilliseconds = 0
                  TotalMinutes = 0
                  TotalSeconds = 0
                }
              Year = 2019
              DateTime = Monday, July 8, 2019 12:00:00 AM
            }
          Day = 8
          DayOfWeek = Monday
          DayOfYear = 189
          Hour = 0
          Kind = Local
          Millisecond = 0
          Minute = 0
          Month = 7
          Second = 0
          Ticks = 636981408000000000
          TimeOfDay =
            class TimeSpan
            {
              Ticks = 0
              Days = 0
              Hours = 0
              Milliseconds = 0
              Minutes = 0
              Seconds = 0
              TotalDays = 0
              TotalHours = 0
              TotalMilliseconds = 0
              TotalMinutes = 0
              TotalSeconds = 0
            }
          Year = 2019
          DateTime = Monday, July 8, 2019 12:00:00 AM
        }
      Day = 8
      DayOfWeek = Monday
      DayOfYear = 189
      Hour = 12
      Kind = Local
      Millisecond = 0
      Minute = 8
      Month = 7
      Second = 46
      Ticks = 636981845260000000
      TimeOfDay =
        class TimeSpan
        {
          Ticks = 437260000000
          Days = 0
          Hours = 12
          Milliseconds = 0
          Minutes = 8
          Seconds = 46
          TotalDays = 0.506087962962963
          TotalHours = 12.1461111111111
          TotalMilliseconds = 43726000
          TotalMinutes = 728.766666666667
          TotalSeconds = 43726
        }
      Year = 2019
      DateTime = Monday, July 8, 2019 12:08:46 PM
    }
}
```

> We could resolve this with PSMore #7857

It is hard to unpack this comment as an outsider without spending a day playing around with PSMore.

I want a way to:
1. UnParse: data type -> string:
    * improve `Format-Custom` so that data types that contain cycles print succinctly/efficiently (either indirectly like DateTime.Date or directly like some domain object models implemented via ORM navigations) 
2. Parse: string -> data type:
    * Take output and convert it back into .NET / PowerShell objects
    * This is really a bonus feature

Separately, I requested the Windows Console team implement "call by intention" escape code handling, such that console streams are structured objects and pipelines to-from programs are basically complex event processing engines.  PSMore seems to tackle the problem "from within PowerShell" but not "across Programs", which was the original promise of "COM Object-Linking-and-Embedding".
